choices.C: It joins all combinations of parent / children processes involving excel.exe
choices.A: It runs a sub-search to locate all detections where excel.exe was blocked
choices.B: It renames a field to drive the main search in order to locate all children processes of excel.exe
choices.D: It renames a field to drive the main search in order to locate all parent processes of excel.exe

questions.question_text:
What is the purpose of the rename command in this query?

event_simpleName=ProcessRollup2 [search event_simpleName=ProcessRollup2 FileName=excel.exe | rename TargetProcessId_decimal AS ParentProcessId_decimal | fields aid ParentProcessId_decimal] | stats count by FileName CommandLine

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B

B. It renames a field to drive the main search in order to locate all children processes of excel.exe
B. To find the parent process you rename ParentProcessID_decimal to TargetProcessID_decimal. To find the the child you rename TargetProcessID_decimal As ParentProcessID_decimal.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct >>>

A similar example from internal Crowdstrike docs:

event_simpleName=processrollup2 [search
event_simpleName=processrollup2 FileName=winlogon.exe
| rename TargetProcessId_decimal AS
ParentProcessId_decimal | fields aid
ParentProcessId_decimal] | stats count by FileName
CommandLine

Explanation:
Show all children of a process (e.g.winlogon.exe) – Looking for typical children of a process, to see outliers
d is correct

Selected Answer: B
B.The unique ID of a target process (in decimal, non-hex format). This field exists in almost all events,and it represents the ID of the process that isresponsible for the activity of the event in focus.
Is there a "Process_Id_decimal" option as Falcon Event?

Selected Answer: B
TargetProcessId_decimal: This field represents the process ID of the process being targeted or acted upon by the event. It's often referred to as the "Falcon PID" and is unique per agent ID.

Selected Answer: B
B. TargetProcessId-decimal

Selected Answer: B
It's B but it should be written like this > TargetProcessId_decimal. It's very misleading, even in the exam is written wrong... 

Also definition of TargetProcessId_decimal from Event Data Dictionary > The unique ID of a target process (in decimal, non-hex format). This field exists in almost all events, and it represents the ID of the process that is responsible for the activity of the event in focus. For example, the TargetProcessId of a process that performed thread injection in an InjectedThread event.

questions.question_text: Which event field contains the Falcon generated ID for a process?

discussion.content: The correct is letter D, because the query has the fields "_time", "ComputerName" and "UserName". And the field "_time" means timestamp of the moment that the event was received by the Crowdstrike cloud ont Event Data Dictionary document. You can run the query "event_simpleName=UserLogon | table _time ComputerName UserName" on event search and see the results.

Selected Answer: D
From the Event Data Dictionary:

"_time: Timestamp of the moment that the event was received by the CrowdStrike cloud. This is not to be confused with the time the event was generated locally on the system. This is the timestamp Of the event from the clouds point Of view. This value can be converted to any time format and can be used for calculations."

Lots of references to the cloud time in there.

Selected Answer: B
B. Human-readable event host time, host name, user name 


Falcon Documentation > Event Investigation > Events > About Events 

_time

Timestamp of the moment that the event was received by the CrowdStrike cloud. This is not to be confused with the time the event was generated locally on the system. This is the timestamp of the event from the cloud's point of view. This value can be converted to any time format and can be used for calculations.

"10/19/2017 18:10:29.396"

comments.content: Based on this information, shouldn't the answer be D then?

discussion.content:
Correct answer is A : Machine-readable event host time, host name, user name
Reference : _time : The host's local time in epoch format."1538648887.051"

https://falcon.crowdstrike.com/documentation/page/e3ce0b24/events-data-dictionary

Selected Answer: D
Event Host Time is identified through ContextTimeStamp_decimal instead.
D _time is the command to covert cloud event time from EPOC to UTC readable.

Selected Answer: B
event host time” and “event cloud time” are two different timestamps that are used to track when an event occurred on the host and when it was ingested into the cloud-based logging service, respectively

Selected Answer: B
I think the correct answer is B. If I run that query it is human readable.
I think the correct answer is B.

questions.question_text:
You initiate a search with the following query:

event_simpleName=UserLogon | table _time ComputerName UserName

What results will display?

choices.B: Human-readable event host time, host name, user name
choices.D: Human-readable event cloud time, host name, user name
choices.A: Machine-readable event host time, host name, user name
choices.C: Machine-readable event cloud time, host name, user name

questions.question_text: What command will eliminate duplicates from a query?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C

C. dedup

Selected Answer: A
A

A. event_simpleName=*written ComputerName=MyPC ContextProcessId_decimal=0123456789 


ContextProcessId is the highlight
C is wrong, as the question specifically asking for Context and not the created one

Selected Answer: A
C is wrong. TargetProcessId_decimal is not a valid field in *FileWritten events. You would use ContextProcessId to trace back its spawner.

questions.question_text:
During an investigation you find out that files are being written to disc by a malicious process. While many are displayed in the detections as context items, you want to see all files written to your host by this process.

What Splunk search would work for this scenario?
